title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur articles from animals trapped in such traps. The Act defines "article of fur" as any furskin or article containing furskin. The terms "furskin", "raw or not dressed", and "dressed" are defined in the Tariff Schedules of the United States. The Tariff Schedules of the United States define terms related to interstate or foreign commerce, import, and person, including individuals, partnerships, corporations, and trusts. The term "person" in the customs laws of the United States includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, trusts, and government entities. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. A "steel jaw leghold trap" is a device designed to capture animals with two steel jaws. A steel jaw leghold trap is a device with two opposing steel jaws designed to capture an animal by snapping closed on its limb. SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. The import, export, or shipment of fur derived from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps is prohibited. It is also illegal to import or transport such traps in interstate or foreign commerce. Any person who knowingly violates regulations regarding the import, export, or shipment of steel jaw leghold traps may face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and imprisonment for up to two years for subsequent violations. The Secretary will reward individuals who provide information leading to a conviction under this Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. Enforcement of the Act is outlined in Section 5. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges can issue warrants for enforcement within their jurisdictions. Federal agencies can assist in enforcing the Act to the maximum extent permitted by law. The Act allows individuals with enforcement authority to detain, inspect, search, and seize packages, make arrests without a warrant for violations, and execute warrants issued by judges for enforcement. Any item seized under this Act shall be held by a person authorized by the Secretary, pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. The Secretary may allow the owner to post a bond instead of holding the item. Forfeited items will be disposed of by the Secretary. The Secretary will dispose of any seized item in a manner consistent with the Act's purposes. Fur or steel jaw leghold traps taken in violation of the Act will be forfeited to the United States. The Attorney General may seek to enjoin violators of the Act. The Attorney General of the United States may seek to enjoin any person alleged to be in violation of this Act or its regulations, leading to forfeiture of seized items to the United States. The Secretary will create regulations to enforce the Act, which will take effect one year after its enactment.
